Hayden Road is the home of Burt Reynolds Hall, once an apartment complex that served as the football team's dorm from 1987 until a 1995 NCAA rule change eliminated athletes-only dorms. It is now set for demolition.
A new FSU dorm, for football players, Champions Hall, rose at Hayden Road and Belle Vue Way.
Wilson Street named for contractor, Lafayette Park builder
Wilson Street, which runs between Meridian Street and Miccosukee Road in the Lafayette Park neighborhoood, is named for William H. Wilson, a Tallahassee contractor and early developer of St. George Island.
Wilson was born in nearby Thomas County, Ga., but grew up in Tallahassee. In 1922, he founded Wilson Construction and Supply Company, which built many of the homes in the Lafayette Park neighborhood. In the early 1960s, he was a co-developer of St. George Island and helped push for the 1965 construction of today's Bryant Patton Bridge from the mainland.
Wilson built the first apartment house in Tallahassee, the Wilsonian Apartments, on a block bounded by Tennessee, Bronough, Call and Duval streets, which had been the site of the Leon Academy, a forerunner of Leon High. The site is now the City Centre parking garage.
Wilson also owned Wilson Beach Cottages at St. Teresa Beach, a complex of cabins originally built for World War II Army officers stationed at nearby Camp Gordon Johnston, which was a training ground for the D-Day invasion. Wilson died in 1969.
LeMoyne: An early French painter of Florida Native Americans
The LeMoyne Center for the Visual Arts is named in honor of France's Jacques le Moyne de Morgues, the first European artist to paint pictures of Native Americans in Florida.
LeMoyne came to Northeast Florida in 1564 as an illustrator and cartographer with the expedition of French explorer Jean Ribault. In addition to landscapes and maps of Florida, LeMoyne painted numerous pictures of indigenous Timucuans, which remain the iconic images of Florida's early residents.
The LeMoyne Art Foundation was organized in 1963 by four Tallahassee women: Nanette Fisher, Clifton Lewis, Mary Metzke and June Strauss. The foundation opened its first gallery in 1964 in the former Deeb House on the northwest corner of Calhoun Street and College Avenue (once a Po' Boys restaurant deck/parking lot).
In 1968, LeMoyne moved to its current home in the historic Meginnis-Munroe House at 125 N. Gadsden St.
Wesson started as school named for a mayor who offered Babe Ruth a job
The school district's multi-use R.N. Gooden-Nancy Russell Center at Wesson on South Meridian Street spent nearly a half century as Leonard Wesson Elementary, which was named for a former Tallahassee city commissioner and Leon County School Board chairman.
The school began in 1946 as Prince Murat Elementary, housed in the former military barracks of Dale Mabry Field. It moved in 1949 to 2813 S. Meridian St., and was renamed South City Elementary. In 1956, it was renamed Wesson Elementary, following the death of Leonard A. Wesson. In 2006, Wesson Elementary merged with Bond Elementary and its building was converted to the Gooden-Russell Center.
Wesson was a Tallahassee city commissioner for one term (1935-38), serving twice as mayor. In 1935, Mayor Wesson offered just-retired baseball star Babe Ruth the position as manager of the Tallahassee Capitals, a minor league baseball team (Ruth declined). Wesson served on the Leon County School Board from 1940-1947, including a stint as chairman.
Wesson died in December 1955, when he suffered a heart attack while turkey hunting. At the time of his death, Wesson was president of the local Coca Cola bottling company and had recently resigned as chairman of the state Game and Fish Commission because of health issues.
Once known as Bullfrog Pond and a place for baptisms, Lake Ella endures
Originally known as Bull Pond (and earlier as Bullfrog Pond), it was originally a natural lake used for baptisms, Emancipation Day celebrations and fishing.
In the 1930s, it was renamed the more pleasant-sounding Lake Ella by the wife of developer William Anderson, who developed the surrounding Anderson Heights housing development.
It remained a popular fishing lake into the 1950s and site of Tallahassee's annual Fourth of July fireworks into the 1970s.
Widening of North Monroe in 1968 led to pollution and it was retrofitted as part of the city's stormwater system.
Now officially known as Fred Drake Park at Lake Ella (Drake was a businessman and civic leader), the park has an encircling sidewalk, gazebo and aerating fountains and is popular with walkers, joggers, bicyclists and ducks.
Laundry owner, county leader lends name to Tom Brown Park
Tom Brown Park is 255 acres of former federal land given to the county in 1972 and named for County Commissioner Tom Brown, who had died the year before.
Brown served two terms on the County Commission and was a businessman who operated several laundries and a service station.
He also had a big background in sports: A former Clemson football star, he spent two years as the Leon High football coach and was a longtime Babe Ruth League baseball coach.
He was renowned for playing first base in city league softball games — without a glove. The county built the original part of the park, which is operated by the city.
As a fitting memory for a coach, Tom Brown Park features several softball and baseball fields, racquet and tennis courts, a disc golf course, a 3.1-mile-long bike and nature trails, and a fenced area for dogs to frolic.
Gibbs Drive and Gibbs Hall named for secretary of state who broke color barrier
A northside Tallahassee street, a Florida A&M University dormitory and a St. Petersburg high school are named for Jonathan Clarkson Gibbs, Florida's first Black Secretary of State, first superintendent of Public Instruction and a delegate to the state's 1868 Constitutional Convention.
Gibbs was born (1821) a free Black man in Philadelphia, graduated from Dartmouth College and became a minister in Philadelphia. After the Civil War, he moved to Charleston as a missionary to newly freed slaves.
In 1867, he moved to Jacksonville and operated a private school before becoming heavily involved in Reconstruction politics.
As Secretary of State (1868-1872), he conducted investigations into the Ku Klux Klan. He was elected to the Tallahassee City Council in 1872 and died in Tallahassee in 1874.
His son, Thomas Van Renssalaer Gibbs, was a co-founder of FAMU in 1887. The FAMU dorm was demolished in 2023 to make way for newer dorms.
Raymond Diehl: Pipefitter, liquor baron and developer
Raymond Diehl Road in northeast Tallahassee is named for Raymond Diehl Sr., a prominent businessman who built a home in the 1930s near the corner of Thomasville Road and present-day Raymond Diehl Road.
Capital Health Plan now occupies the site. Originally, the road was a dirt trail from Thomasville Road to near Centerville Road. Construction of I-10 in the early 1970s severed the road into the current two pieces on either side of I-10. Diehl was a pipefitter who operated a plumbing supply store then segued into real estate development.
After Leon County voters approved liquor sales in 1960, Diehl and his son, Raymond Jr., opened five liquor stores (later sold to the ABC Liquor chain). For 53 years, Raymond Sr.'s wife, O'Neill Diehl, operated O'Neill's Fairy Tale Shop, a popular children's clothing store.
In the early 1980s, Raymond Diehl Jr. and his wife, June, developed the Betton Place shopping center, where June operated the upscale Haystack clothing store for 17 years.
Raymond Diehl died in 1968 of a heart attack while hunting; O'Neill Diehl died in 1988. Raymond Diehl Jr. died in 2003.
Gaines Street and Gainesville named for famed Army general
Gaines Street, one of Tallahassee's most notable thoroughfares, is named for a famous 19th century U.S. Army general, Edmund Pendleton Gaines.
Gaines was born in 1777 in Virginia, where his great-uncle and his father were prominent in the American Revolution. As a young military officer, Gaines was responsible for surveying Mississippi and constructing the Natchez Trace road. In 1807, Gaines arrested former U.S. Vice President Aaron Burr in Alabama on charges of treason and transported Burr to Richmond, Va., where he was acquitted in a trial.
Gaines became a hero of the War of 1812, when he commanded forces that prevented the British from taking Fort Erie. He played a prominent role in the first two Seminole Wars (1817-1818, 1835-1842) and spent several years arbitrating disputes between white settlers and Native Americans. Gaines opposed removal of Native Americans from their traditional lands and gained a reputation for treating the tribes fairly.
In 1824, the first Florida territorial council to meet in Tallahassee made Gaines one of the first names attached to a Tallahassee street. Cities in Florida, Texas and Georgia were named Gainesville. Fort Gaines, a historic fort near Mobile, is named for him. Gaines died in 1849.
Coincidentally, Col. Edmund Pendleton Gaines (possibly a descendant), was the third of four base commanders of Dale Mabry Field, Tallahassee's World War II Army Air Corps base. Col. Gaines served at Dale Mabry from Sept. 1943 through June 1944 – gaining notoriety in October 1943 when he threatened to make Tallahassee off limits to military personnel because of an outbreak of venereal disease.
Venereal disease became a statewide epidemic in 1943, as Florida became the training ground for hundreds of thousands of military personnel. Gaines sent a letter to the city officials calling for "more aggressive measures to control prostitution and promiscuity." The crisis eventually waned.
State owns historic Brokaw-McDougall House
The Brokaw-McDougall House is the well-landscaped two-story home at Meridian Street and Miccosukee Road. It was built by pioneering businessman Peres Bonney Brokaw.
Born in 1814 in New Jersey to French immigrants, Brokaw arrived in Tallahassee in 1840. He and a partner began a successful livery business at Calhoun and Pensacola streets, which operated until the Civil War.
Brokaw built his home from 1856 to 1860 — a period during which he also served on the Tallahassee city council, Florida House of Representatives and Florida Senate. Following Brokaw's death in 1875, the house passed to a daughter, who married businessman Alexander McDougall (who, after his wife's death, married another of Brokaw's daughters). The McDougall descendants continued to live in the home until it was sold to the state in 1973.
The family's original 640-acre property, stretching a half-mile east along Miccosukee Road, once encompassed all of today's Leon High School property and was filled with crops and cows. Brokaw elaborately landscaped the area around the home — and according to unproven legend received advice from Frederick Law Olmstead, the landscape architect who designed New York's Central Park.
In 1998, the state leased the home to the city, which hosted weddings, receptions and art shows. In 2011, the state reclaimed the property to house its Division of Cultural Affairs.
Late Cherokee Hotel connected to Jim Morrison of The Doors
The 2012 pardon of the late rock singer Jim Morrison by Gov. Charlie Crist for a 1969 Miami conviction had many readers wondering: Where was the Cherokee Hotel?
"Room 206, Cherokee Hotel," was the address Morrison gave to Tallahassee police in September 1963 when he was arrested for disturbing the peace while a student at FSU.
As longtime residents know, the 4-story Cherokee Hotel was on the southwest corner of Park Avenue and Calhoun Street (across the street from the Knott House).
The Cherokee Hotel was built in 1922 and demolished in 1964. One presumes it was a temporary address in 1963 for Morrison, as the transfer from St. Petersburg Junior College looked for an apartment following the start of classes five days before.
Nylic Street an abbreviated named for business interest of Wadsworth's
Streets of a small enclave of rental houses and apartments near FSU are named for its developers — and an insurance company.
Howell Wadsworth, a Tallahassee real estate entrepreneur and insurance executive, once owned land at West Tennessee and Brevard streets, where, among other things, he was responsible for creating a housing development in the early 1950s.
The street that runs off Tennessee Street is named Wadsworth; another is named Hancock, for Wadsworth's development partner, Melvin Hancock. A third street is named Nylic, an acronym for New York Life Insurance Company, for whom Wadsworth was an agent for 40 years.
Wadsworth owned numerous tracts of land in Tallahassee, including parcels that include today's Riley Elementary School (for which he donated the land), Callen neighborhood, Fourth Quarter restaurant and a downtown square on Tennessee Street between Bethel Missionary Baptist Church and the federal building.
Wadsworth's late wife, Alice, was the sister of Florida Gov. LeRoy Collins; his son, Murray Wadsworth, is a longtime Tallahassee attorney. Howell Wadsworth died in 1985.
Gardens of Edenfield: A couple's legacy inspires road name
Edenfield Road, which connects Miccosukee Road to the Mahan Highway, is named for Lawrence and Isabella Edenfield – who became famous for allowing townspeople to grow vegetable gardens on their property on Edenfield Road.
Lawrence, a native of Grand Ridge, was a teacher and principal at several North Florida schools, then worked for the state Department of Education. Isabella was a native of Indiana, who taught at Leon High and worked for the Dean of Public Administration at FSU. They married in 1928 and had two children. In the late 1940s, the couple bought a 90-acre tract at the southwest corner of Miccosukee Road and Edenfield Road, then a dirt road.
Starting in the 1950s, the Edenfields began allowing needy FSU students and neighboring Black residents to grow vegetables in plots on their land. The Edenfields eventually expanded the program, providing space for professors, physicians, attorneys and other Tallahassee residents to grow vegetables. Lawrence Edenfield prepared and provided the land for free for many years (eventually charging a token $5 per row per year).
The garden program ended shortly after the deaths, just two months apart in 1979, of Lawrence (January) and Isabella (March). The Edenfields' farm house still stands, though it's now located on Berklie Drive — a name created out of the initials of the Edenfields, their daughter and son-in-law.
Mabry Manor has WWII street names
The streets of Mabry Manor are named for World War II generals and soldiers because it was once the home of Tallahassee's World War II Army Air Corps base — though the streets were not named for military personnel when it was a base.
Dale Mabry Air Field existed from 1941-1945. It occupied 559 acres bordered by present-day Roberts Avenue (on the north) and Mabry Street (east). The streets of the military base were identified by letters (Avenue C, Avenue D, etc.) and numbers (Third Street, Fourth Street, etc.). After the base closed, the land reverted to the city, which gave it to FSU, which used it as its West Campus from 1946 to 1956.
In 1952, at the request of the U.S. post office, the city gave the streets new names, honoring U.S. military leaders such as Dwight Eisenhower, Douglas MacArthur, Hap Arnold, Matthew Ridgway, George Patton, etc. Nininger Street was named for Army Lt. Alexander Nininger, the first World War II winner of the Medal of Honor.
After FSU departed, the former base became home to the Mabry Manor housing subdivision and Sabal Palm Elementary School. A short distance west, also off Roberts Avenue, is Seminole Manor, a housing development built by Syde Deeb from 1948 to 1950.
Duval Street named for man who set our capital status
This north-south artery in downtown Tallahassee, as well as Jacksonville's Duval County, is named for the first civilian territorial governor of Florida, William Pope DuVal (who capitalized the V in his last name).
DuVal had been a U.S. Congressman from Kentucky and territorial judge in St. Augustine, before serving as Florida governor from 1822 to 1834 — making him the longest-serving governor in state history. Under DuVal, Tallahassee was chosen as the capital of Florida, and DuVal lived in a home in today's Myers Park.
A colorful raconteur who ran away from home as a teenager, DuVal once shared a stagecoach ride with author Washington Irving, who recounted DuVal's adventures in a short story titled "The Early Experiences of Ralph Ringwood." DuVal moved to Texas in 1848 and died in 1854.
Red Barber Way honors voice of Dodgers, NPR
The street encircling WFSU television and radio studios, as well as a camellia garden in the downtown Chain of Parks, is named for legendary major league baseball announcer Walter "Red" Barber, who lived the last 20 years of his life in Tallahassee.
Barber broadcast for three major league teams, most famously the Brooklyn Dodgers, where he popularized such colorful terms as "rhubarb" and "sitting in the catbird seat."
After retiring from broadcasting, Barber penned numerous books, wrote a weekly column for the Tallahassee Democrat and appeared every Friday on National Public Radio's "Morning Edition," where he often extolled the beauties of Tallahassee camellias.
Barber died in 1992.
Bloxham gets park, street, building as governor who urged creation of FAMU
William Dunnington Bloxham was a Tallahassee native who became Florida's first governor to serve two times (1881-1885 and 1897-1901).
His most notable achievements were selling four million acres of the Everglades for $1 million to restore the state's financial stability and urging creation of what became Florida A&M University.
Bloxham died in 1911 and is buried in St. John's Cemetery. His one-time home at 410 N. Calhoun St. has been restored and is used for offices.
Bloxham Park is between Monroe and Calhoun streets in the Park Avenue chain of parks.
Bloxham Street runs between Gadsden Street and M.L. King Boulevard.
The Bloxham Building, in the 700 block of South Calhoun Street, is the former Caroline Brevard Elementary.
College Avenue originally called Clinton Street
College Avenue, the street that basically runs from downtown to the gates of Florida State University, spent nearly a century named Clinton Street.
Like many early Tallahassee street names, the name was applied at the time of the city's founding in 1824 to honor a national leader, either George Clinton, a U.S. vice-president under two presidents (Jefferson and Madison) or New York statesman Dewitt Clinton.
Though the original incarnation of FSU opened its doors in 1857, the street name was not changed to College Avenue until 1916. By then, the western end had been paved (1912), broadened from 24 feet to 30 feet and lined with oaks and stately private homes (since demolished or remodeled into businesses and sorority/fraternity houses).
Neamathla led tribe near Lake Lafayette
A residential street in northeast Leon County, Neamathla Trail, is named for the most significant Native American in Tallahassee history: Neamathla, who gave Americans "permission" to establish Tallahassee as the capital of Florida.
Neamathla was the chief spokesman for Seminoles in the negotiation of the September 1823 Treaty of Moultrie Creek, which attempted to relocate Seminoles in Florida. Territorial Gov. William DuVal praised Neamathla as "the greatest man you will see among the Indians, who controls his warriors with as much ease as a colonel his regiment."
Neamathla led the larger of two tribes occupying the Tallahassee area; the older Chefixico led the smaller band. Both tribes lived near Lake Lafayette, east of Tallahassee.
In October 1823, territorial commissioners John Lee Williams and William Simmons, met with Neamathla to tell him of the new territory's plan to locate its capital in Tallahassee. Neamathla objected but gave his grudging approval with the stipulation they not tell other Seminoles of his consent.
A year later, Neamathla threatened to make the streets of Tallahassee "run red with blood," unless the white settlers left.
DuVal, backed by a regiment of U.S. Army soldiers, met with Neamathla and his 600 warriors. DuVal illegally deposed Neamathla as head of the Seminoles, and ordered the Native Americans to a reservation near Tampa. The confrontation was retold by famous author Washington Irving, a friend and chronicler of DuVal, in the story "The Conspiracy of Neamathla."
Neamathla later participated in the 1836 Creek War, was captured and sent to Oklahoma, where he died in 1841.
Blountstown named for Seminole chief
Blountstown, county seat of nearby Calhoun County, is named for John Blount, a Seminole chief whose reservation was near the present city.
Blount was sympathetic to the United States, serving as a guide for Andrew Jackson in the first Seminole War (1818). In 1823, he was one of two Seminole chiefs exempted from the Moultrie Creek Treaty (designed to move all Seminoles to Central Florida) and given their own reservations.
By the late 1820s, Blount was being regularly attacked by other Seminoles, who considered him a traitor and in 1834 the U.S. moved Blount and his followers to Texas. Blount was robbed of his U.S.-provided expense money by slave traders and other Native Americans during the move, then died shortly after arriving in Texas.
Blount's real name was Laufauka, meaning "One Who Endures."
He became known as Blount because he reportedly shared character traits with William Blount, a Tennessee governor, U.S. Senator and superintendent of Indian Affairs. In Tallahassee, there is the Blountstown Highway (State Road 20) and Blount Street (south of Gaines Street, between Adams Street and M.L. King Boulevard).
Neil Kirkman Building named for father of FHP
The Florida Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles building on Apalachee Parkway is named for the man who was the founding director of the Florida Highway Patrol (1939) and the first HSMV executive director (1969).
Raised in Palatka, Neil Kirkman served in both world wars.
In 1936, he was appointed director of the short-lived State Road Department Patrol.
In 1939, he was appointed commander of the newly created FHP, with an original force of 32 officers statewide.
After World War II, where he rose to the rank of colonel, he returned to build FHP into an agency of more than 2,300 officers. The Kirkman building was built in 1958.
Kirkman retired in 1970 and died in 1973.
Arvah Hopkins named for city power player
Arvah Hopkins was the Tallahassee city manager from 1952 to 1974 and a scion of one of Leon County's oldest families.
Hopkins oversaw creation of Tallahassee's city-owned utility company, the building of a new airport and the planting of 50,000 dogwood trees.
Hopkins was a descendant of an owner of Goodwood Plantation and great-grandson of territorial Gov. John Branch. His older brother, Bill, was the longtime Leon County prosecuting attorney, who won ground-breaking convictions of four white youths for the 1959 rape of a Black Florida A&M co-ed.
Arvah Hopkins is memorialized in the electric power generating station on Geddie Road, the Arvah Branch housing development and Arvah Branch creek in eastern Leon County.
Hopkins died in 1976.
St. Teresa Beach: How it got its sainthood is unknown
This 2-mile stretch of summer homes along St. George Sound in Franklin County was settled in 1873 on land deeded from Gov. William Bloxham to three prominent Tallahassee landholders: Arvah Hopkins, Patrick Houstoun and Joseph John Williams.
It was named for Teresa Hopkins, daughter of Arvah Hopkins, who once owned Goodwood plantation and was the grandfather of longtime Tallahassee City Manager Arvah Hopkins. No one knows when or why "Saint" was added to the name.
Located 50 miles southwest of Tallahassee, it was originally a two-day trip by horse-drawn wagon, including a ferry ride across the Ochlockonee River. The heart of the development, sometimes called Old St. Teresa, consists of 15 lots along the bay and 15 lots behind those.
During World War II, the homes were leased to the Army officers of nearby Camp Gordon Johnston.
Dempsey Mayo: A Florida Supreme Court marshal and landowner
Dempsey Mayo Road, a mile-long road connecting Mahan Drive with Miccosukee Road, is named for a former Florida Supreme Court marshal who owned land on the road: Dempsey Bryan Mayo Jr.
Mayo was born in 1919 in Ocala and moved to Tallahassee in 1936 to work as an auditor for a private business.
He served in the Army during World War II, then returned to Tallahassee where he went to work for the state's Division of Vocational Rehabilitation.
In 1949, he was hired as the Supreme Court marshal, responsible for custody and maintenance of the Supreme Court building as well as security and purchasing for the justices.
Mayo served 25 years as marshal before his retirement in 1974.
Over time, Mayo, who lived on Piedmont Drive, acquired a sizeable number of acres in what was then rural eastern Leon County.
He sold the land in individual homesites; many around Maylor Road, named because it connects Dempsey Mayo and Taylor roads. Dempsey Mayo Road is home to Westminister Oaks retirement community and W.T. Moore Elementary School.
Mayo, who was married and had one daughter, died in 1981.
Broward Street named for higher education-minded governor
One of the state's most famous governors, Napoleon Bonaparte Broward, had his name applied to one of Florida's most populous counties — and one of Tallahassee's residential streets, which runs three blocks from Apalachee Parkway to East Park Avenue.
During Broward's governorship (1905-1909), he initiated the draining of the Everglades and the consolidation of Florida's hodge podge of state-funded colleges into a system of three colleges (today's Florida, Florida State and Florida A&M universities) under a Board of Control.
Broward, who piloted a Spanish blockade-running tugboat supplying Cuban revolutionaries during the Spanish-American War, was elected a U.S. Senator in 1910 — but died before he took office.
Perkins from a pioneer family that owned Myers Park land
Perkins Street, a southside street between Meridian and Adams streets just north of Magnolia Drive, is named for George Perkins — a 20th century Tallahassee attorney who once owned the land that became the Myers Park, Country Club and Woodland Drives neighborhoods.
A descendant of a pioneer Tallahassee family, Perkins was born in 1870 and educated at the University of Virginia. Married in 1900, Perkins built a home at 118 N. Gadsden Street in 1904. Because his wife and his daughter were very heavy he had an elevator installed in the home in the 1930s so they could reach the second floor.
In 1912, he bought the 1,400 acre former Lakeland Plantation from the Houstoun family. The plantation encompassed most of the land now bounded by Magnolia Drive, Apalachee Parkway, Meridian Street and Cascades Park.
In 1924, Perkins sold the city 200 acres for the establishment of Capital City County Club and golf course. In 1925, he sold the city 47 acres for the creation of Myers Park. In the 1930s, he platted the Woodland Drives neighborhood.
Perkins died in 1941; in 1943, his wife and daughter donated Old Fort Park to the city. The Perkins home now serves as offices.
Proctor and Yancey led city when Levy Park streets were named for them
Proctor and Yancey streets in the Levy Park neighborhood are named for Tallahassee's mayor and city manager at the time they were platted in 1946. The streets were named by longtime Tallahassee developer Syde Deeb and comprised his Circle Beautiful residential subdivision.
Ralph Proctor was a star football lineman at Leon High in the early 1920s, owned Proctor Oil Company, helped found the Tallahassee Bank, served one term (1943-1946) as a city commissioner and was a beloved Boy Scout troop leader. He died in 1987. One of his two sons is famed Tallahassee sculptor Sandy Proctor.
Malcolm Yancey spent 25 years as a State Road Department engineer before being hired as City Manager in 1940. Yancey was ousted by city commissioners in 1952 (and replaced by Arvah Hopkins) when Yancey opposed the eventually thwarted attempt by commissioners to sell Tallahassee's municipally owned electric power company to a private corporation. Yancey returned to the SRD (today's Department of Transportation) for many years before his death in 1969.
One of his 10 children was the late Bert Yancey, a professional golfer who won seven PGA Tour tournaments; one of his grandsons is Yancey Sutton, the former Leon High and University of Florida football star.
Claude Pichard started lumber company
Claude Pichard Drive, a residential street straddling Magnolia Drive by Tallahassee Memorial Hospital, is named for the youngest of three Pichard brothers who founded a local lumber and construction company in 1909.
After the brothers— Alphonse, Eugene and Claude — dissolved their partnership in 1917, Claude Pichard continued to build homes throughout Tallahassee (Alphonse and his son continued Pichard Bros. hardware store for many years). Claude Pichard also bought a swath of land along Magnolia Drive from Miccosukee Road to Alachua Drive.
After Pichard's death in 1946, his five children received homesites on Magnolia Drive and the remainder of the land was sold to developers Julius Parker and Harold Brock.
The men developed Brockswood Park residential neighborhood (now part of the Old Town neighborhood). Parker named streets for his daughter (Lucy), son (Frederick), great grandmother (McLendon), great grandparents (Browning) — plus Claude Pichard.
Meginnis Arm named for plantation owner
The southern-most, arm-like projection of Lake Jackson (and an adjacent residential road) is named for Daniel B. Meginniss, who owned a plantation in that area along the lake in the 19th century.
Meginniss was also a partner of Arvah Hopkins, an early owner of Goodwood Plantation, in a general store and land investing. Meginniss was a member of an early Tallahassee pioneer family from Maryland. Joseph R. and George H. Meginniss were early settlers of Leon County and George owned a successful general store.
Perhaps the best known Meginniss descendant was Daniel's nephew, Benjamin Andrews Meginniss, who was a Leon County judge, Tallahassee city commissioner (1923-1929) and mayor. An amateur historian, who published numerous articles in the Tallahassee Democrat, Benjamin Meginniss died in 1972 at age 88.
Castelnau Court named for artist who sketched cascade, early Capitol
Castelnau Court, a short residential street off Old St. Augustine Road, honors the 19th century French visitor who produced the earliest sketches of Tallahassee.
Francis comte de Castelnau (1810-1880) was a naturalist, artist and diplomat. He was born in London and studied natural science in Paris. He came to Florida in 1837 at the beginning of a four-year scientific expedition in the United States and Canada.
He produced several drawings of Florida's frontier capital, Tallahassee — including three famous, frequently reprinted images. One shows Florida's first permanent Capitol, another shows Jefferson Street between today's City Hall and Leon County Courthouse — and the third is the only known image of the famous cascade, or waterfall, that inspired Tallahassee's selection as the capital of Florida and Cascades Park.
Castelnau later made a scientific exploration of South America. He went on to serve 30 years (1848-1877) as a French consul in Siam (Thailand) and Australia.
Park, Adams dividing line for city addresses
Many might assume downtown's main intersection of Tennessee and Monroe streets form the dividing lines for Tallahassee addresses.
But every street direction and street number in Tallahassee is actually determined from the intersection of Park Avenue and Adams Street.
Park Avenue is the dividing line for north and south; Adams is the dividing line for east and west.
Buildings facing south and east have even numbers; buildings facing north and west have odd numbers.
Though Tallahassee streets were first named in the 1820s, the assignment of directions and numbering didn't begin until the 20th century.
In 1902, Park Avenue (then McCarty Street) and Boulevard Street (now M.L. King Boulevard) were established as the dividing lines. In 1903, building numbers were instituted.
In 1927, Adams Street replaced Boulevard as the dividing line for east-west designations; Adams Street, which originally passed behind the west entrance to the Capitol, was more of a main street then than it is today.
In 1927, the Tallahassee City Commission also eliminated two-digit numbers in the first blocks on either side of the dividing streets, instituting today's numbering system that starts with numbers in the 100s.
In 1902, Tallahassee had only 23 named streets. Named streets stretched only from Georgia (north) to Gaines (south), and from Gadsden (east) to Gay (west).
FAMU football, track star built Paremore Estates
Paremore Estates, a subdivision off North Meridian Road, is named for the Black family that has lived on land in the area since Reconstruction — and the late Florida A&M football and track star, Bob Paremore, who developed the subdivision.
A freed slave, Martin Paremour, was the first to settle on the land. His sons, Martin Paremore and Sandy Parramore (family members have used all three surname spellings), later bought 40 acres each between Lake Jackson and Meridian Road.
In the 1970s, Martin's grandson, Bob Paremore, developed Paremore Estates, once marked by a football-shaped sign in FAMU colors. Paremore was a two-time All-American running back at FAMU, a track star and teammate in both sports of the late Olympic gold medal winner and NFL star Bob Hayes.
One of the streets in Paremore Estates is named China Doll — Paremore's nickname from birth, because he was a small infant with long lashes and hair. Paremore, who coached and taught at Godby High School for 33 years, died in 2004.
Jim Lee Road named for city's star golfer
This long residential street from Magnolia Drive to south of Paul Russell Road, passing Rickards High School, is named for Jim Lee Jr., one the most talented golfers in Tallahassee history.
Lee, whose father was a Florida Comptroller (1933-1946), worked for state government and owned a 180-acre cattle ranch where Rickards now sits.
But he gained fame as one of the state's top amateur golfers.
He was a two-time winner of the Florida Amateur championship (1946, 1950). He won numerous regional tournaments and finished in the top 10 of several open professional tournaments.
In 1960, as president of Capital City Country Club, he organized the Tallahassee Open, the city's first professional golf tournament. After Lee's death in 1965, the tournament was renamed the Jim Lee Open, which was one of the city's top amateur tournaments.
Street recognizes 1933 FAMU grad
Pinder Street, stretching from Osceola Street to behind the student union on the Florida A&M University campus, is named in honor of a famous U.S. agriculture adviser and FAMU grad.
Frank Edward Pinder, a native of Key West, earned a degree in agriculture from FAMU in 1933. He spent many years as a county farm agent in Florida before working nearly 40 years in Africa for the the U.S. Department of State and United Nations. Pinder won innumerable awards and honorary degrees for his work in improving food-production practices in Africa. He became a friend of legendary Ethiopian leader Haile Selassie and Liberian President William Tubman.
Pinder also became a prolific collector of African artifacts and art. In 1983, he donated his collection to the FAMU Black Archives, including one of the world's largest collections of antique Christian artifacts from Africa.
Pinder was inducted into the FAMU Hall of Fame in 1962. He died in 1992 in Maryland. FAMU named the street for him in 2003.
Goodbread Lane named for the smell of baking bread
Goodbread Lane, according to its chief historian O'Neal Jackson, is named for what it suggests: the smell of good bread.
Goodbread Lane is a two-block enclave of homes, just west and parallel to the 700-800 blocks of North Macomb Street. It was originally an unnamed dirt lane with more than three dozen families crowded into duplex-style small homes.
Jackson, 69, a former Leon County school teacher, sports coach and football referee raised on adjacent Macomb Street, said the name developed in the 1940s, when residents baked breads and cakes for Sunday dinners on Saturday afternoons.
He said Beatrice McPherson, a domestic worker who lived off nearby Gibbs Street, walked through the community every Saturday on her way downtown, proclaiming, "There is some good bread cooking here." Jackson said children in the neighborhood began calling her the "Good Bread Lady," and the name was eventually adopted by residents to describe where they lived: "We lived where the good bread is cooked," Jackson said.
The street name first appears in the 1948 city directory. The street was paved about 1980; the former duplexes have been remodeled into single family homes. Most current residents of Goodbread Lane were raised on or have family connections to the street, which lends its name to the neighboring low-income housing project, Good Bread Hills.
Everhart a local pioneer in special education
Gretchen Everhart School, a public school for children ages 3-22 with intellectual disabilities, is named for the first coordinator of special education for Leon County schools.
Gretchen Everhart, who had braces on her legs from a childhood disability, was a native of Escambia County.
Born in 1908, she began her teaching career in 1929 shortly after she graduated from high school. She taught for 15 years before accepting a position teaching in a school for disabled children. In 1947, she came to Tallahassee, where she earned her bachelor's and master's degrees from Florida State University.
She taught one year at a school for disabled children in St. Petersburg, before accepting a position in Tallahassee in 1951, teaching a special education class at Prince Murat Elementary (later the now-defunct Leonard Wesson Elementary).
Famed for her cheerful, forceful personality, she spent nine years (1962-1971) as coordinator of special education before retiring in 1971.
Tallahassee's first school entirely for special needs children was opened and named for her in 1972. Everhart died in her native Pensacola in 1973.
McMillan oversaw National Guard Armory
The National Guard Armory on Easterwood Drive near Tom Brown Park is named for the late Henry W. McMillan — a Tallahassee-reared soldier who oversaw all the state's National Guard units from 1962-1975 as the Florida Adjutant General.
Henry William McMillan Jr., was born in Mississippi, moving to Tallahassee with his family when he was 15. The seventh of 10 children, he was an older brother of Vernelle Tucker, a ground-breaking woman executive for the Tallahassee Democrat, who died Jan. 14.
McMillan graduated from Florida High and enlisted in the National Guard in 1929. McMillan worked several jobs in Tallahassee, until he joined the Internal Revenue Service in 1937. He married Tallahassee resident Louise Ford in 1932 and they had two daughters.
McMillan rose from private to captain in the National Guard. In 1940, he was called to active duty for World War II. McMillan rose to colonel, commanding an infantry unit that fought in the Pacific. He was later sent to South America, where he served on the task force for the military treaty for the Organization of American States.
Deactivated in 1946, he returned to the IRS, becoming a division director in Tampa and Jacksonville. In 1962, he retired from the IRS for a full-time position as the Florida National Guard Adjutant General, stationed in St. Augustine. When McMillan retired in 1975, he was the longest-serving member in history (46 years) of the Florida National Guard.
The armory, built in 1970, was named for McMillan in 1976. McMillan died in Orlando in 1990 and is buried in Tallahassee's Roselawn Cemetery.
Koucky Park: The name before the Nenes
This 2.8-acre park in Indian Head Acres was given to the city in 1955 by George Koucky, who was one of the major developers of the east side neighborhood.
Koucky developed the neighborhood with John and Irene Stead, who had bought the 500-acre former Indian Head Plantation in 1947 and gave the streets their Native American names (all streets include the word "nene," which means "trail" in the Creek language).
The park is connected through a wooded path to busy Optimist Park, a one-time lake filled in by the county.
Koucky, a native of Arizona who moved to Tallahassee in 1946, died in 1997.
Tharpe street named for Dairy farmer
Tharpe Street originally existed for only one long block from North Monroe Street to Meridian Road and was created by the developers of Anderson Heights, which was a housing development built in the 1930s and 1940s around Lake Ella.
The developers named it for the previous owner of the land, G.C. Tharpe, who operated a dairy farm. In 1947, it began a series of extensions west. Today it stretches five miles to Capital Circle Northwest.
The two-lane road was widened to four lanes from Monroe Street to Ocala Road from 1989 to 1996.
Anne Street: Ten-year-old's question to commissioner gets her a road name
Anne Street, a short service road connecting Crestview and Mitchell avenues at the south end of Winthrop Park, was named for retired Florida State University Dean of Faculties Anne Rowe — when she was a child.
In July 1956, when she was 10 years old, Rowe lived on Crestview Avenue, where her neighbor was Tallahassee city commissioner Joe Cordell. Noting that the short street had no name, Rowe went to Cordell and asked why — which led to the city commission unanimously voting to name the street "Anne Street."
Rowe, the daughter of longtime attorney Bob Ervin and the niece of one-time state Attorney General Richard Ervin, earned a Ph.D. in literature from the University of North Carolina. She joined the FSU faculty in 1972 and became the school's third Dean of Faculties in 2003.
Spanish mission borders San Luis Ridge
San Luis Ridge is a west-side neighborhood that adjoins historic Mission San Luis, which sits on the highest part of a ridge that runs westward through the residential neighborhood.
The mission existed from 1656 to 1704 and was the capital of a string of Spanish missions across North Florida. The neighborhood was developed by the late David Avant Jr. and his late brother, George, in the mid-1950s.
David Avant Jr., an artist, entrepreneur and historian, named the development's streets in honor of the inhabitants of the 17th century mission. The dozen or so streets include the names of Apalachee chiefs (Don Patricio, Don Andres, Domingo), Spanish priests (Miranda, Mendoza) and Spanish soldiers (Perez, Francisco, Solana) among others.
Though the mission and neighborhood are commonly pronounced San Loo-wee, the correct Spanish pronunciation is San Loo-weese.
Old Fort Park: A Civil War era touchstone designed to keep the Capitol Confederate
One of Tallahassee's most quaint features is Old Fort Park, a moat-surrounded earthworks erected during the Civil War.
Legend holds it was hastily constructed in March 1865 when U.S. Army troops landed at St. Marks during the Civil War. But apparently the fort was one of several constructed around Tallahassee in 1864 when the Union victory in the nearby Battle of Marianna revealed the capital city's vulnerability.
The safeguard proved unneeded as Confederate troops and volunteers repulsed federal troops at the Battle of Natural Bridge, 10 miles south of Tallahassee, on March 3, 1865.
Originally known as Fort Houstoun (HOUSE-ton), it was built on Lakeland Plantation, owned by Edward Houstoun, whose 1,280 acres encompassed today's Myers Park and Woodland Drives neighborhood. The plantation was bought in 1912 by Tallahassee attorney George Perkins, who developed Woodland Drives (1920s, 1930s) and donated the land for Capital City Country Club (1924).
The Perkins family donated the fort to the city in 1943. The one-acre park is bounded by Seminole, Maple, Country Club and Santa Rosa drives.
Hodges Drive named for father of homestead exemption
This short street behind Tallahassee Memorial Hospital is named for State Sen. William C. Hodges and his wife, Margaret, owners of nearby historic Goodwood Mansion.
Hodges served in the legislature from Leon County from 1923 to 1939, ran unsuccessfully for governor twice and was largely responsible for passing Florida's homestead exemption law in 1935 as Senate president.
Hodges bought Goodwood in 1925, and his passion for horticulture laid the foundation for today's gardens.
Hodges died in office in 1939; his widow, Margaret, continued living at Goodwood and remarried Army officer Thomas Hood. Margaret died in 1978 and Hood died in 1990, bequeathing the house to the nonprofit foundation that operates Goodwood Museum and Gardens.
Ausley Road named for physician patriarch of prominent family
Ausley Road in west Tallahassee is named for physician and longtime Leon County Commissioner Charles Ausley — whose son, grandson and great granddaughter became equally prominent Tallahassee residents.
Charles Merritt Ausley was a native of Camden, S.C., who earned an undergraduate degree at the University of Tennessee and his medical degree at the Baltimore College of Medicine. He came to Tallahassee in 1901 and established a medical practice. In 1906 he married Elizabeth Saxon — daughter of George Saxon, founder of Capital City Bank and Tallahassee real estate magnate.
Ausley was such a beloved physician that numerous babies he delivered were named in his honor. Ausley Road, which runs from Pensacola Street south across Jackson Bluff Road, was named for him in the 1920s.
Ausley also was involved in local politics. He served several years on the city council, before Tallahassee switched in 1920 to the city manager-city commission form of government. He was elected to the county commission in 1917, remaining 23 years until his death on Nov. 22, 1940.
One of Ausley's two sons, Charles Saxon Ausley, became a prominent attorney, and was a city commissioner and mayor (1940-1944). Ausley's grandson, Charles Dubose "Duby" Ausley, is a prominent attorney and was the longest serving member (15 years) of the now-defunct Florida Board of Regents, which oversaw state universities.
Ausley's great granddaughter, Loranne Ausley is an attorney who served in the Florida House of Representatives from 2000 to 2008 and in the state Senate from 2020 to 2022.
Smith Hall named for FSU math professor, assistant football coach
Florida State University's Smith Hall residence hall was named for Elmer Riggs Smith, who was an FSU math professor for 39 years — and one of the school's first assistant football coaches.
Smith, a native of Tennessee, earned a master's degree from Vanderbilt University and spent two years at the University of Chicago.
He was hired in 1903 at Florida State College, the co-educational forerunner of Florida State College for Women, which was the forerunner of Florida State University. FSC fielded a football team from 1902-1904, with Smith serving as assistant coach to FSU's second head coach, Jack "Pee Wee" Forsythe. Football was dropped in 1905, when FSC became FSCW; it was resurrected in 1947, when FSCW became FSU.
The 10-story Smith Hall, originally called West Hall, was completed in 1952 and hailed as "the tallest building between Jacksonville and Pensacola." It was FSU's second on-campus dorm for men and became co-ed in the mid-1970s. Smith retired as a math professor in 1942. He died in Tallahassee in 1959. The dorm was demolished in 2017.
Gadsden Street was originally Butler Street
Gadsden Street was originally named Butler Street for one of Tallahassee's most prominent early residents, Robert Butler, the first surveyor general of Florida.
Butler was a protégé of and Army officer with Andrew Jackson. Butler came to Tallahassee in 1824 and opened a surveying office/home on the site of today's Supreme Court.
He established the prime meridian marker, the spot in Cascades Park from which all Florida surveys originate, and designed Florida's first capitol building. He established a plantation near today's Lake Jackson Mounds State Park, where he and his wife hosted the "Feast of Roses," an annual springtime celebration.
Early maps show today's Gadsden Street named Butler Street and today's Meridian Street named Gadsden Street. It is believed one of Butler's assistant surveyors named the street for Butler — which Butler later changed because he felt it inappropriate.
The name of fellow Jackson officer James Gadsden was moved to Butler Street and Gadsden Street was renamed Meridian Street — as it runs north from the prime meridian.
Shephard Street was named for fallen World War II hero
Shephard Street — a two-block-long northside street from M.L. King Jr. Boulevard to Ford Street — is named for Marion "Buddy" Shephard, a Tallahassee native killed during World War II.
Shephard was a Leon High grad who enlisted in the Army in 1942 and won a Purple Heart while fighting in North Africa before being killed Oct. 30, 1944, in Italy. Shephard grew up in his family's home at the corner of North Boulevard Street (now M.L. King Blvd.) and a then-unnamed street. In August 1945, the City Commission named the previously unnamed street in honor of Shephard, at the request of his year-older brother, John.
The family home was renumbered 404 Shephard St.. John Shephard lived at 412 Shephard, next door to the family home, until a few years before his death in 2005 — and he named his daughter, Marion, in honor of his fallen brother.
Can you imagine Park Avenue as McCarty Street?
The name seems obvious enough today, given that seven blocks of it straddle the downtown Chain of Parks. But this street was originally named McCarty Street, for an early judge and territorial secretary, W.M. McCarty.
Legend holds its name was changed to the more affluent-sounding Park Avenue when one of its residents, Jane Chittenden, didn't want an Irish street name printed on the invitations to her son's wedding. Actually, Chittenden was president of a local women's group that successfully petitioned the city in 1905 to change the street name to reflect its relationship with the downtown parks.
Her descendants insist it was just coincidental her son's wedding occurred at the same time. The street now extends from Florida State University to Capital Circle Southeast.
Carraway key to legislating FSU-UF rivalry
Carraway Street is named for the Tallahassee state senator who co-authored the bill creating co-educational Florida State University — and backed a 1955 bill that would have forced FSU and Florida to play football.
Franklin Wilson Carraway was a Tallahassee native, who graduated from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Business, and became a banker. The son-in-law of Tallahassee entrepreneur Lewis Lively, Carraway and his brother-in-law, future Tallahassee mayor Leonard Wesson, also operated their father-in-law's Coca Cola bottling company for several years.
Carraway served in the Florida House of Representatives (1945-1949) and the Florida Senate (1955-1966). In 1947, he was a co-sponsor of the bill that created co-educational institutions at previously all-male University of Florida and Florida State College for Women (FSU).
In April 1955, Carraway backed a bill that would have compelled the long-established UF to play the still-new FSU in football. The bill was defeated 19-15 in the Florida Senate. Gov. LeRoy Collins and presidents of the two universities later hammered out the agreement that started the series in 1958.
Carraway Street is in the Capital Hills neighborhood, between Mahan Drive and Miccosukee Road, just east of Magnolia Drive. The street was named for Carraway by developer Horrie Culpepper Sr., who developed the neighborhood in the early 1950s. Wilson Carraway died in 1972.
Shuttered city hydroelectric plant named for former power superintendent C.H. Corn
The former C.H. Corn Hydro-Electric facility at the Lake Talquin dam was named for the city's former superintendent of power production, Clemer Herbert Corn.
Corn, born in 1923, was a native of Pikeville, Indiana. He was in the U.S. Navy during and after World War II, serving as a gunner's mate on two ships. He became a mechanical engineer and worked many years for the Jacksonville Electric Authority. He came to Tallahassee in 1972, as superintendent of Tallahassee's then-two power plants. He was married for 49 years to the former Lucky Strickland and they had four daughters.
The hydro-electric plant was built in 1929, when the Ochlockonee River was dammed to create Lake Talquin. It was run by Florida Power until 1970, then was abandoned until the city acquired it in 1978. The city received a federal grant and made it operational again in 1986, when it was named for Corn, who oversaw its acquisition.
The C.H. Corn Hydro-Electric facility, off State Road 20 in western Leon County, was one of only two hydro-electric plants in Florida. It produced about one percent of Tallahassee's electric power, operating only when rainfall fills Lake Talquin and allowed water to pass through the dam and power the generators.
Corn retired in 1987. He died in 1997 at age 74 and is buried in Tallahassee's Roselawn Cemetery. The city moved to abandon the facility in 2017 to pursue solar power.
Cemetery a remnant of Betton Plantation
A Florida historic marker on Betton Road recognizes one of the few remaining plantation cemeteries that once dotted Leon County.
The Plantation Cemetery at Betton Hills was the burial ground for slaves and servants of the 19th century Betton Plantation. The 1,200 acre plantation was owned by Turbott Betton, who bought the land from the estate of the French general Marquis de Lafayette, who received land in Tallahassee for his service to the United States during the Revolutionary War. Betton died in 1863 and the land was purchased by the Winthrop family.
In 1945, Guy Winthrop began developing the present-day, 800-home Betton Hills neighborhood — and struck a deal in which the city would maintain the cemetery in exchange for the land that became Winthrop Park in Betton Hills. By the 1990s, the cemetery had become overgrown and the neighborhood association persuaded the city to resume its maintenance of the cemetery.
The historic marker was erected in 1999. The marker is on the north side of Betton Road between Trescott Drive and West Randolph Circle. Only a handful of gravestones remain in the cemetery, where most graves were originally marked with wooden crosses.
Edward Conradi served as FSU president for 32 years
The longest serving president in Florida State University history was Edward Conradi. He was selected as the school's third president in 1909 and served until 1941.
A native of Ohio, with a Ph.D. in psychology, Conradi oversaw the prime years of Florida State College for Women (1905-1947). During his 32-year leadership, FSCW grew from 13 acres, five buildings and 237 students to 88 acres (plus the Seminole Reservation and FSU dairy farm), 20 buildings and more than 2,000 students.
Conradi created an honors program, won the first Phi Beta Kappa chapter in Florida and led FSCW to become the first woman's college in the South approved by the Association of American Universities. He died in 1944.
The school's original biology building was named for him and the psychology department's first endowed chair was named in his honor. A street connecting West Tennessee and West Call streets also bears his name. There is a statue of Conradi in the Williams Building courtyard, which adjoins the Augusta Conradi Theater, named for his wife of 29 years who died while he was in office.
Torreya tree led to local Garden of Eden theory
A short northside street in Tallahassee, Torreya Drive, as well as various businesses in North Florida, are named for a unique conifer tree found in only a few places in the world — including Torreya State Park, 45 miles west of Tallahassee on the Apalachicola River near Bristol.
The tree was named about 1835 by Hardy Croom, the original owner of Tallahassee's Goodwood Plantation, who named the tree in honor of 19th century American botanist John Torrey.
The tree gained notoriety in the 1960s, when it was promoted by E. E. Callaway as proof the biblical Garden of Eden was located in Torreya State Park (where the tree has been imperiled for decades by a fungus).
Elvy Edison Callaway was a Bristol attorney and unsuccessful Republican candidate for governor in 1936, who became a Baptist minister. Callaway based his theory on the Bible's reference to a river running out of Eden that branched into four rivers (as does the Apalachicola River) and the Bible's assertion Noah built his ark out of gopherwood — a name also used for the Torreya tree.
A Torreya tree, planted by Croom in 1835, stood outside the Old Capitol until construction of the new Capitol in the early 1970s. Callaway died in 1981.
Northeast streets named for banking family
The street names of a northeast Tallahassee neighborhood near Lake Jackson pay homage to one of the most prominent Tallahassee residents, and his family, of the early 20th century: Dexter Lowry.
Dexter Marvin Lowry, born in 1876 in Valleyhead, Ala., came to Tallahassee in 1900 as general manager of Florida Cotton Oil Company. He was elected to the city council in 1904 and was elected mayor eight consecutive years from 1910 to 1917. In 1918, he was elected state senator from Leon County, serving two legislative sessions (1919, 1921).
In addition to the cotton oil company, Lowry joined the board of Capital City Bank. In 1920, he became president and majority owner of the bank, and remained in that position until his death in 1936. His widow sold the bank to the Smith family, which continues to operate the now-publicly owned bank.
Dexter's 16-year-younger brother, Fred Lowry, moved to Tallahassee in 1925 and joined his brother at Capital City Bank. Fred Lowry served three years on the city commission (1946-1948), including a term as appointed mayor. Fred Lowry helped organize the Florida-Georgia minor league baseball league in the late 1930s, serving as league president and president of the Tallahassee Capitals baseball team. Fred Lowry died in 1985.
Dexter Lowry's daughter, Mary Maxwell "Tipper" Lowry, married Frank Sampson "Pint" Shaw, who founded Tallahassee Ford in 1920. The Shaws bought the 650-acre Meridian Plantation on Lake Jackson in 1946. Their son, Frank Jr., later took over the car dealership and ran it until he sold it in 1988.
In the 1980s, the Shaws developed a portion of Meridian Plantation as the Pine Tip Hills neighborhood on the north side of Rhoden Cove Road. Frank Shaw Jr. named the streets for his father, his daughter Sally, his sister Tennie, his grandmother Letitia and his grandfather Dexter. He also named streets for previous owners of the plantation: Uncle Glover (Rawls) Road and Dwight Davis Drive.
There is also a Lowry Drive off Piedmont Road.
Park, Legion post named for father and son, Ben Bridges
Tallahassee's first city softball field was named for longtime treasurer-clerk Ben Bridges.
The city's American Legion post is co-named for his son, Ben Bridges Jr. Ben Bridges, a native of Andalusia, Ala., graduated with a degree in chemistry from the University of Florida in 1905. He moved to Tallahassee to be Assistant State Chemist with the Department of Agriculture.
In 1911, he was hired as city clerk, and became city treasurer-clerk in 1920. In 1938, the city built its first softball-only diamond between South Monroe and Adams Streets, just south of Gaines Street, and named it Ben Bridges Park. The city softball program moved to Messer Field in 1963; a state parking garage now occupies the former Ben Bridges Park.
Bridges was severely injured in a 1940 car crash on Thomasville Road and died in January 1941.
Ben Bridges Jr., a University of Florida tennis star, died in a plane crash in April 1942 while piloting an Army Air Corps plane in California — becoming the first UF grad and first Tallahasseean killed in World War II.
Tallahassee's Sauls-Bridges American Legion Post 13 is named for Bridges Jr., and Claude Sauls, the first Tallahasseean to die in World War I.
Sampson Hall named for FAMU football founder
This five-story men's dormitory at Florida A&M University is named for George M. Sampson, founder of the FAMU football team.
The dorm, originally named South Hall for Men, was built in 1938.
Sampson joined the FAMU faculty as a professor of mathematics in 1899 upon graduation from Western Reserve University in Ohio (now Case Western Reserve University).
Sampson, who had played football at Western, organized and coached FAMU's first football team.
Two years later, Sampson and another football-playing faculty member, Jubie Bragg, laid out a field a mile south of campus.
Sampson, who served in a variety of teaching and administrative roles, left FAMU in 1909.
After World War I, a football field was established on the site of today's track and field complex — just south of Sampson Hall — before moving in 1957 to its present site and being named for Jubie Bragg and his son, Eugene, FAMU's first All-American football player.
Lake Talquin and its merged name
The 8,850-acre lake is named for the two cities it lies between: Tallahassee and Quincy.
It was created in 1927 by construction of the Jackson Bluff Dam on the Ocklockonee River. The dam was created to provide hydro-electric power for the surrounding area. Shallowest at the eastern end, its depth ranges from 15 to 40 feet, with the deepest areas in the former river channel. It is filled with numerous trees and tree stumps that were once part the forest that surrounded the river.
It is surrounded by the 30,000 acre Talquin State Recreation Area, which includes the Lake Talquin State Park on the southern and southwestern shores of the lake.
Kleman Plaza named for visionary city manager
It's startling to realize it's been more than a quarter century since Kleman Plaza opened — and thus many residents may not even know the origin of its name. It's named for Dan Kleman, who was Tallahassee's city manager from 1974 to 1994.
The choice of Kleman, who was only 28 years old then and from "up North" (Dayton, Ohio), was considered a bold one by the city commission in 1974, following the retirement of Arvah Hopkins.
Descended from Leon County pioneers, Hopkins had led city operations for 22 years. But the cool and cerebral Kleman proved up to the challenge, guiding Tallahassee through two decades of unprecedented growth and progress – including construction of the multi-building plaza that has become an integral part of downtown.
Kleman, who went on to posts in Hillsborough and Duval counties, later became the director of the Jacksonville Fire and Rescue Department.
TPD officer Ponce De Leon honored after being murdered in line of duty
Tallahassee Police Department Officer Ernest Ponce de Leon was the first TPD officer murdered in the line of duty. A street on the east side of TPD headquarters on Seventh Avenue is named Officer Ponce Way in his honor.
Ponce De Leon, 40, and a father of two, was shot and killed July 8, 1988 at a laundromat near the corner of Lake Bradford Road and Levy Street. Ponce De Leon and Officer Greg Armstrong had been called to investigate a carload of suspicious people, three of whom were escapees from a Maryland prison who opened fire on the officers.
Ponce De Leon died after being shot twice in the chest; Armstrong fired 13 times, wounding all three men, who were captured at a nearby house. Clarence Jones, then 33, was convicted of killing Ponce De Leon and sentenced to death; he died on Florida's Death Row.
In 1988, on the 10th anniversary of the shooting, city officials named the street for Officer Ponce de Leon. In 2002, TPD officer Dale Green became the second TPD officer killed, when he was ambushed during an investigation of a home invasion. Officer Christopher Nicholas Fariello was killed in 2022 when his patrol vehicle collided with a car being driven by a man who was fleeing the police.
Fred Lee Park honors man who integrated TPD
The statue at the corner of Macomb and Georgia streets, and the little park behind it, are named for the first Black sergeant on the Tallahassee Police Department.
Fred Lee was a cafeteria cook at Leon High in 1952 when city fathers convinced him to integrate the police department.
He was not treated equally at first: He had no squad car and had to call white officers to complete arrests he initiated.
But Lee eventually was given the same powers as all officers, received his own squad car and climbed to the rank of sergeant before retiring after 20 years.
Lee died in 1973. One of his sons, Fred Lee Jr., is a Tallahassee singer.
The park and statue were unveiled in 2002.
Oakland is city's second-oldest cemetery
An annual Memorial Day observance is held in Oakland Cemetery, which is the city's second-oldest public cemetery and includes a veterans section. The cemetery is presumably named for its profusion of oaks and other trees.
Oakland Cemetery was created in 1902 and stretches north from Brevard Street to Fourth Avenue, bordered by Bronough Street on the east and originally by Macomb Street on the west. In 1905, the city gave up the western portion for creation of old Lincoln High and a city park (today's Fred Lee ballfield).
The veterans cemetery was begun in 1936 in the southeast corner of Oakland and has 170 gravesites of veterans who participated in conflicts from World War I to Vietnam.
The Old City Cemetery, laid out during the 1841 yellow fever outbreak, was Tallahassee's first public cemetery. In 1937, Greenwood Cemetery was established for Black people — after city officials decreed Oakland's Black section had reached capacity — followed by Roselawn (1955) and Southside (1963) city cemeteries.
Streets named for governors
Many of the Tallahassee streets named for early Florida governors are the result of a street renaming project by the City Commission in 1930.
The commission eliminated many duplicate names by giving streets new names — and approved the suggestion of Mayor Frank Moor to use the names of former governors for many of the new street names.
The process produced the modern-day streets of Allison, Branch, Broome, Broward, Brown, Drew, Fleming, Gilchrist, Jackson, Jennings, Martin and Reid.
The process also eliminated separate names for street extensions and formalized a previously unwritten policy in which north-south streets in Tallahassee were designated streets and not avenues. Tallahassee underwent similar street renaming projects to eliminate duplicate names in 1948 and in 2001.
Early settlers dubbed it the Yellow River
The Ochlockonee River forms the western boundary of Leon County between Gadsden and Liberty counties – and is one of the oldest identified natural features of Florida.
Spanish explorer Hernando de Soto was the first European to discover the river, crossing it in 1540 on his way to the Mississippi River after spending the winter of 1539-40 in Tallahassee. De Soto named the river Guacuca. Later Spanish called the river Amarillo, and the first English-speaking settlers in the area called it the Yellow River for its color.
Native Americans called it oki, for water, and lakni, for yellow. English speakers eventually adopted phonetic spellings of oki lakni, creating a host of spellings through the years before arriving at the current Ochlockonee. The river originates in Georgia, just north of Moultrie, which was originally called Ocklockney.
In 1927, the Ochlockonee River was dammed to create Lake Talquin and provide hydro-electric power.
But the river continues south from the dam to Franklin County, and empties into Ochlockonee Bay; the longtime Angelo's Restaurant is on the bay. The Ochlockonee River State Park, where the river merges into the bay, was established in 1970.
Murphree was only FSU, UF president
A short thoroughfare between West Tennessee and Call streets on the west side of FSU is named Murphree Street — for the only person ever to serve as president of FSU and the University of Florida.
Albert Alexander Murphree, a native of Alabama, was hired as a math instructor in 1895 at West Florida Seminary, FSU's original incarnation. Two years later, at age 27, he was elevated to president and married the daughter of a Tallahassee trustee of the university. Murphree guided the school's metamorphosis into Florida State College and in 1905 presided over the conversion to Florida State College for Women, after losing a bid to be president of the newly consolidated University of Florida.
In 1909, he was hired as UF's second president. Murphree reorganized the Gainesville school, oversaw creation of its colleges of education, pharmacy and journalism and the construction of 10 new buildings. Murphree was promoted as a candidate for governor and even U.S. President before he died while university president on Dec. 5, 1927 at age 57.
The University of Florida erected a statue and named a dormitory for Murphree. FSU named its Jennie Murphree dormitory for his wife, a graduate of FSCW, and erected its statue of Murphree in front of the dorm. Both Murphrees are buried in Tallahassee's St. John's Episcopal Cemetery.
McCaskill Avenue named for early city commissioner
McCaskill Avenue, which runs west off Lake Bradford Road, is named for Allen Peter McCaskill, one of the first three people elected to the Tallahassee City Commission in 1920 — and one of two people to serve as a city commissioner and city manager at the same time.
Before 1920, Tallahassee was governed by an elected mayor and an 8-9 member city council. In 1920, Tallahassee adopted the appointed city manager/elected city commission form of government. McCaskill, Guyte McCord and James Stuart Lewis were the only three people to run for the city commission in 1920. McCaskill was the leading vote-getter (100 votes), earning him a three-year term.
Following the 1922 resignation of the first city manager, J.W. Greer, McCord and McCaskill each spent nearly a year as interim city managers while continuing to serve on the commission. In 1923, McCaskill won a second three-year term on the city commission before retiring from government in 1926.
McCaskill, a native of South Carolina, was born in 1871. He was married in 1904, though his wife died 10 months later. He and several family members moved to Tallahassee in 1907, where he purchased a large farm on Lake Jackson and raised cattle and crops. In 1913, he sold his farm and earned a living in livestock sales, lumber and construction. He died in 1941.
Blair Stone Road named after telephone company exec, not a rock
Longtime Tallahasseeans know Blair Stone Road is correctly written as three words — not two, as in Blairstone Road — because Blair Stone was a person.
Stone was a Tallahassee telephone company executive and civic leader whose name was first affixed to the street that bears his name in the 1950s — when it was just a dirt road between U.S. Highway 27 (Apalachee Parkway) and Old St. Augustine Road.
It was one of many previously unnamed roads — such as Olson Road and Gearhart Road — that were named for employees of the telephone company, which needed to assign names to streets when they added phone service to new areas.
Stone died in 1959.
Gilchrist named for principal
Gilchrist Elementary, on Timberlane Road, is named for its first principal, James "Mack" Gilchrist.
A native of Alabama, Gilchrist served with the Marines during World War II, seeing combat in the South Pacific, including Guadalcanal. After the war, he moved to Tallahassee where he earned bachelor's and master's degrees from Florida State University and worked at the Sweet Shop.
He taught school at Kate Sullivan Elementary, Cobb Middle School and Chaires School before becoming principal at Sealey Elementary. In 1966, he became the first principal of the newly opened Timberlane Elementary.
Upon his retirement in 1979, the school was renamed Gilchrist Elementary — marking the first time a Leon County school was named for a living person. Gilchrist died in 2010.
Rogers Hall honors FSU English prof
Rogers Hall, a dormitory at Florida State University, is named for the university's first Distinguished Professor of the Year, William Hudson Rogers.
A native of Plum Branch, Va., Rogers graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Davidson University, and taught high school for two years before earning a master's and Ph.D. in English from the University of Virginia and serving in World War I. He joined the faculty of Florida State College for Women in 1922, and taught for 42 years in the English department.
The handsome, athletic Rogers was a favorite of women students and renowned as one of the nation's leading scholars on poet Robert Browning. In 1957, Rogers was voted by faculty members as the inaugural winner of FSU's Distinguished Professor of the Year award. Rogers, the author of three books, retired from FSU in 1964 and died in Tallahassee in 1975. The 8-story Rogers Hall on the west side of campus opened in 1969.
Rogers and his wife, Mary, had two daughters: Elizabeth, who died in 2012, was a Miss Tallahassee and wife of former circuit and appeals Judge Guyte McCord Jr.; Isabel, who died in 2007, was a noted Presbyterian Church official and college professor.
Knott House known for Emancipation reading
The annual Emancipation Day celebration is held at the Knott House, from whose steps Union Gen. Edward McCook read the Emancipation Proclamation on May 20, 1865 — officially signaling the end of slavery in Florida.
The historic house at 301 E. Park Ave. was built in 1843 by free Black George Proctor, who built many antebellum homes in Tallahassee. It was originally occupied by attorney Thomas Hagner and his wife, Catherine Gamble.
In 1928, it became the home of Luella and William Knott, who spent 38 years in the Florida Cabinet (1903-1941) as state treasurer and comptroller; his wife was a poet, who published several books. Following their deaths in 1965, their son, Charlie, lived in the home until his death in 1985, when he willed it to the former Historic Tallahassee Preservation Board. In 1997, the home was transferred to the state, which operates it as a museum.
Hartsfield dairy becomes school, street namesake
Almost anything in Leon County named Hartsfield traces to Thomas Hartsfield, a farmer from North Carolina who migrated to Leon County in the 1830s and fathered 12 children.
The eastside elementary school, opened in 1956, is named for his grandson, Frank S. Hartsfield, a Leon County superintendent of schools for 20 years (1916-1936). The westside road is named for descendants who operated Hartsfield Farm, a large dairy operation between Hartsfield Road and Old Bainbridge Road; the dairy operated until the 1960s and softball tournaments were later held on the property.
Tom's great grandson was the late Paul Hartsfield, longtime Leon County Clerk of the Courts (1960-1992), who was the father of Bert Hartsfield, longtime Leon County Property Appraiser (1993-2015).
According to family lore, former Atlanta mayor, William Berry Hartsfield, namesake of the Atlanta airport, was the grandson of Tom Hartsfield's brother.
DeGraff Hall gets moniker from prof
DeGraff Hall, a two-building, five-story Florida State University dormitory complex at Tennessee and Dewey streets is named for the late Mark DeGraff, a popular FSU professor and administrator.
DeGraff was a native of New York, who earned degrees at Colgate University, American College of Osteopathy and Iowa State University. He came to Florida State College for Women in 1925 as a professor of education and in 1928 published a noted social studies textbook.
By 1947, when FSCW became FSU, DeGraff was supervisor of the testing bureau, responsible for administering all standardized tests.
DeGraff Hall, originally a two-story dorm, was built in 1950 as FSU's first men's dorm and later became the graduate student dorm. DeGraff died in 1957; the dorm was named for him in 1961.
The original structure was demolished in 2005 to make way for the current complex, which opened in 2007. In 1985, the FSU College of Social Work established a scholarship in the name of Mark DeGraff and his wife, Lula Hamilton DeGraff.
Chapel Drive named for former military church
Chapel Drive, which connects West Pensacola and West Call streets, is named for a former military chapel moved there in 1957 to serve as home for Westminster Presbyterian Church. The church placed the chapel over a basement, covered it with bricks, added four columns and a steeple.
The chapel was one of two identical chapels at Dale Mabry Field, the World War II Army Air Corps base in southwest Tallahassee. In 1954, five families from Tallahassee's First Presbyterian Church founded Westminster Presbyterian in one of the chapels. In 1957, the church bought the chapel and moved it to a 12-acre former dairy farm on a hill overlooking FSU.
The church sold eight acres to a developer, who built homes for FSU professors on the adjacent Westminster Drive. The late Nobel Prize winner Paul Dirac and his wife lived across the street from the church.
Chapel Drive was originally a dirt road from Pensacola to the church, before being paved all the way to Call Street in the early 1960s.
The second chapel at Dale Mabry Field was purchased, moved to 2821 South Monroe Street and also covered with bricks. It is now home to New Life United Methodist Church.
In 2000, Westminster Presbyterian moved to 4501 Centerville Road.
Road named for Andrew Jackson's crossing site
Jackson Bluff Road in Tallahassee is named for the place on the Ochlockonee River where Andrew Jackson crossed into present-day Leon County — 196 years ago today.
Jackson and his army ranged through North Florida in 1818-1819 as part of the first Seminole War. On March 29, 1818, following a five-day march from the Apalachicola River through present-day Tate's Hell swamp, they reached the Ochlockonee River. According to historian Dale Cox, the river was high but Jackson ordered his men to build canoes and the next day, March 30, 1818, they crossed the river and followed a Native American trail into the area of present-day Tallahassee.
Two years later, settlers came to Gadsden County and dubbed the area where the soldiers crossed as Jackson's Bluff. During the Second Seminole War, Fort Braden was built to guard the river crossing.
Settlers also used a Native American trail to reach Tallahassee, when it became the capital of Florida (1824) — though the original route would have been roughly today's State Road 20/West Pensacola Street.
In 1927, the Ochlockonee River was dammed to create Lake Talquin and provide hydroelectric power from the Jackson Bluff Dam, built near Jackson's crossing point. The C.H. Corn Hydro Dam became one of only two hydroelectric dams in Florida. It was shuttered in 2017.
Today's Jackson Bluff Road, which runs parallel to West Pensacola Street, was created and named in 1927, when Gaines Street was extended west of Lake Bradford Road.
Elliot Building named for civil engineer who drained the Everglades
The Elliot Building is a small state building on South Monroe Street across from the Capitol named for Fred Cotten Elliot, who supervised the draining of the Everglades in the early 20th century.
A native of Leon County, Elliot earned a civil engineering degree from Virginia Military Institute and worked in New York, Arizona and Mexico before returning to Tallahassee in 1908 to work for the Internal Improvement Trust, which oversaw state swamp lands. Beginning in 1911, Elliot conducted, designed and oversaw the state's surveying and drainage of the Everglades to provide farmland. He also designed the St. Lucie canal that controls drainage of Lake Okeechobee.
Elliot spent 48 years with the Internal Improvement Trust (now a part of the Department of Environmental Protection), serving as chief engineer and secretary to the board for 28 years. Elliot designed the first giant swamp buggies that allowed construction crews and farm workers to operate in the marshes of the Everglades. Elliot also laid out the first few holes of the Capital City Country Club golf course in 1924.
The Elliot Building was built and named for him in 1962 as home of the Internal Improvement Trust and Volunteer Florida. Lawmakers set aside $2 million to demolish the building to make way for a Memorial Park.
Elliot died in 1963 at age 85.
Obelisks memorialize two early St. John's church leaders
At St. John's Episcopal Church, 211 N. Monroe St., the two granite obelisks flanking the front sidewalk are memorials to two of the church's 19th century founders. The northern obelisk is for J. Loring Woart, the pastor who oversaw construction of the church in 1837. The southern obelisk is for Hardy Croom, a member of the congregation that began in 1829. The two men died within nine months of each other in separate tragedies at sea.
Bryan and Hardy Croom were North Carolina planters who came to Leon County in the 1830s and bought vast tracts of land. The Crooms were the original owners of Goodwood Mansion and plantation. Hardy Croom and his family were sailing to Florida in October 1837 when their steamship sank in a storm. The presumed order of their deaths became the basis of a lawsuit that served for nearly a century as the precedent for Florida laws about survivorship and inheritance.
Woart was a native of Massachusetts and Harvard graduate, who was pastor of St. John's in 1836-1838, overseeing construction of the church. In June 1838, Woart, his wife and four members of St. John's were on a steamship to New York, when the boiler exploded and the ship sank. Woart and his wife stayed alive for several days by clinging to debris but eventually drowned.
Evening Rose streets were named for landowners
The streets of the Evening Rose neighborhood, off Capital Circle NE near Mahan Drive, are named in tribute to the land's longtime inhabitants as well as the developer's family. Evening Rose was started in 2006 by Dave Wamsley and Fincher Smith; it was acquired by another company in 2010.
The 36-acre development was originally part of a 132-acre farm belonging to Alexis Stanley, a son of slaves in North Carolina who moved to Leon County after the Civil War. Stanley fathered 14 children with two wives. Alexis Lane, across Capital Circle, is named for Alexis Stanley and his descendants continued to live on or owned much of the original farm.
In Evening Rose, Easter Stanley Road is named for one of Alexis' daughters. Easter Stanley married Hubert Davis, and raised a large family on the property; one of her daughters, Parthenia Austin, was head baker at FAMU and famous for baking cakes for local weddings. Austin Davis Avenue is named for the two families who sold the land to Wamsley and Smith.
Genevieve Park Drive is named for Wamsley's grandmother. Brush Hill Road is named for the road in Nashville where Wamsley grew up, across the street from country music star Roy Acuff.
The name Evening Rose was suggested by the Austin and Davis families, linking another branch of the family. The neighborhood includes the Imagine School at Evening Rose.
